J. P. BIERMANN, F. J. J. G. JANSSEN* Joint Laboratories and other Services of the Dutch Electricity Supply Companies, KEMA, Chemistry Department, P.O. Box 9036, 6800ETArnhem (The Netherlands) M. DE BOER, A. J. VAN DILLEN, J. W. GEUS and E. T. C. VOGT University of Utrecht, Inorg. Chem. Dept., Croesestraat 77A, 3522 AD Utrecht (The Netherlands) (Received July 19,1989; revised October 3,1989) Summary MoOa on SiOg catalysts are suitable for the selective oxidation of ammonia into nitrogen (N3) and water. The catalysts were prepared by homogeneous deposition precipitation using electrochemically reduced pre- cursors. The experiments were carried out at atmospheric pressure and at temperatures ranging from 200 to 400 C. Nitrogen and water yields of up to 100% at temperatures over 375 C were obtained when ammonia and excess oxygen in helium were passed over a MoOa on SiOg catalyst. Catalysts containing less than 15 wt.% MoOa gave rise to no conversion of ammonia. The presence of small amounts of lead in the catalyst appeared to influence the conversion of NHa in a positive way. However, the presence of nitric oxide in the feed did not influence either the conversion of ammonia or the selectivity to nitrogen. The nitric oxide concentration remained constant during the conversion of ammonia. The results indicate that species reducible by hydrogen at 540 C are related to the activity of the catalysts. Introduction Emission of ammonia causes air pollution. Removal of ammonia can be carried out using selective oxidation to nitrogen and water. Since formation of nitrogen oxides must be prevented and at temperatures up to 500 C no homogeneous reaction takes place, a selective catalyst is needed to perform the oxidation of ammonia. Selective oxidation of ammonia in car exhaust gases may also be interesting. To deal with nitrogen oxides, very expensive rhodium is required, over which nitrogen oxides can be easily reduced to nitrogen and ammonia. Subsequent oxidation of ammonia must lead selectively to molecu- lar nitrogen. *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/90/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 230 Janssen and Van den Kerkhof [1] have described the oxidation of ammonia over V205/WOa on TiOg, WOa on TiOg and Ve^Oy on SiOg catalysts. Though the WOa on TiOg and FezOa on SiOg catalysts were highly selective in the oxidation of ammonia to nitrogen and water, the activities were low. The activity of the VgOs/WOs on TiOg catalyst was higher, but the selectivity to nitrogen was low. Moreover, the presence of nitric oxide appeared to suppress the oxidation of ammonia. This paper describes the performance of PbO/MoOa on SiOg catalysts which exhibit higher selectivities and activities in the oxidation of ammonia to nitrogen and water than the catalysts described earlier. The effect of NO on the oxidation has also been investigated. The catalysts have been prepared by means of homogeneous precipitation from homogeneous solution onto silica. To establish a sufficiently strong interaction of the precipitating molybdenum species with the silica support, Mo(III) was precipitated instead of the more stable Mo(VI). For comparison purposes, two Mo(III) solutions were prepared using a Pt or a Pb electrode. Non-supported MoOa was also investigated. Both a commercially available ultrapure MoOa sample (Cerac) and a MoOa sample prepared by precipitation of Mo(III), nitration, drying and calcination were studied. The MoOa prepared by precipitation ofMo(III) contained many more lattice defects than the commercially available MoOs. Earlier it was shown that ammonia reacts with the surface of suitable metal oxides to give surface hydroxyl groups and, presumably, adsorbed nitrogen atoms. Adjacent surface hydroxyl groups which are present on reduced metal ions desorb as water, leaving an oxygen vacancy behind. This vacancy is subsequently filled by oxygen from the gas phase. Filling of the surface vacancy brings with it reoxidation of the reduced metal ions. Nitrogen species adsorbed on neighboring sites react to desorb molecular nitrogen. The above mechanism implies that reduction of the catalytically active metal oxide is an important step in the catalytic oxidation of ammonia. Since the deposited molybdenum species which strongly interact with the silica surface may be difficult to reduce, the activity of these species may be low. Therefore temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was used to assess the reducibility of the molybdenum species present on the catalysts. The dispersion of the molybdenum moieties in the different catalysts was established in the transmission electron microscope (TEM). In the catalytic experiments, the concentration of the different gaseous components was determined mass spectrometrically. Experimental Catalyst preparation The catalysts used are listed in Table 1, together with their main characteristics. In all catalysts the same silica support was used. A reduced molybdenum precursor was used because such precursors give better interaction between the active material and the silica support [3]. The reduced precursors were prepared by electrochemical reduction ofMo6"1" ('molybdic acid', HgMoC^-xHaO, Merck 'zur Synthese') to Mo3"1" in 8 M HC1. A very low pH level is required to dissolve the Mo64^ and to stabilize the Mo^ as the hexachloride ion MoClg3". Either Pb or Pt electrodes were used. Pb electrodes have the advantage of showing a relatively high overpotential for the production of Hg. However, catalysts prepared using the precursor obtained with the lead electrode were con- taminated with lead. The 'platinum' prepared catalysts however, contained no platinum. In this paper catalysts containing lead will be indicated as Mo(Pb). The precipitation of MoOa on silica was performed in a precipitation vessel as described previously in the preparation ofVgOs on SiOa [4]. The valence of the Mo-species was analyzed spectrophotometrically before preci- pitation. A suspension of the support (SiOz, Degussa Aerosil 200V, specific surface area 186 n^g"1) in demineralized water was acidified to a pH of about 0.5 using hydrochloric acid. The suspension was stirred under nitrogen for several minutes in the precipitation vessel, after which a given amount of the Mo^ solution was added. Precipitation of the molybdenum species onto the support was brought about by the slow injection of a dilute solution of sodium hydroxide or ammonia at a rate of 0.1 mmol OH" min~1. Injection was generally stopped when the pH had reached a level of 8-9. After precipitation the catalyst was filtered, washed and dried in air at 120 C for -20 h and then calcined in air at 350 - 400 C for -72 h. 232 Catalytic experiments The apparatus used in the ammonia oxidation experiments is described elsewhere [1]. The experiments were carried out in a fixed-bed reactor with an i.d. of 3.8mm. The detection of the reactants and products was performed using a sector mass spectrometer (Varian MAT 112). Both the Pyrex reactor and the stainless steel tubing of the system showed no activity during the experiments. Ammonia in helium, oxygen in helium, nitric oxide in helium and high purity helium were used. All gases were used without further purification. The initial composition of the gas mixture was 500 ppm NHa and 2% 02, with helium as balance. The overall gas flow was 100cm3 min"1 and the catalyst weight was 50 mg. Before use, the catalysts were pressed at 4 atm for 2 min and then crushed and sieved to particle diameters ranging from 0.25 mm to 0.50 mm. The catalysts were calcined in situ, using helium containing 25% oxygen at 400 C for 1 h. All experiments were reproducible and mass balances were accurate to within 5%. Temperature-programmed reduction TPR measurements were carried out using hydrogen in a standard TPR setup. Commercially available hydrogen (5%) in argon was used without further purification. The gas flow was about 50 cm3 min"1 and the catalyst weight was about 80 mg. The heating rate was 10 Cmin~1 and the temperature varied from 200 to 850 C. Figure 1 shows the concentrations of reactants and products over MoOs (Cerac) as a function of the temperature. Significant features are: (i) low ammonia conversion; (ii) NaO is produced; (iii) the N3 concentration profile shows a maximum at about 375 C; and (iv) a decrease in nitric oxide concentration. In contrast to the results of the experiments with MoOa (Cerac), the MoOa (HDP) does not produce NgO and behaves in a manner similar to the supported catalysts (see Fig. 2). Discussion Previously, we described the mechanism of nitric oxide reduction with ammonia to form N3, HgO and NgO, both in the presence and in the absence ofOg, over the catalysts Va05, V-fls on TiOg, VgOg on SiOa/AlgOa and Va05 on AlgOs [5,6]. Evidence was given that NHs does not react with Og or 0 from any source during the reaction, but that N3, HgO and NzO were produced by a reaction involving all three species, NO, NHa and Og. In the mechanism proposed, NHs chemisorbs on the surface of the catalyst, resulting in a nitrogen-containing species and an OH group. Subsequent reaction of the dissociated ammonia species in the presence of NO leads to the formation of N3, HgO and NgO. Another step in the mechanism is the dehydration of the surface, creating an oxygen vacancy. This vacancy is immediately occupied by one oxygen molecule. When a vacancy arises next to the adsorbed oxygen molecule, Og dissociates and one of the atoms becomes adsorbed on the vacancy, with the other remaining on the original site. In a previous paper [7], it was suggested that for the molybdena catalyst the mechanism of the insertion of molecular oxygen is identical to that for the vanadia system. However, the behaviour of nitric oxide over the 237 molybdena catalyst is different from its behaviour over the vanadia catalyst. From the results shown in Figs. 2 and 3 it may be concluded that nitric oxide does not react with the chemisorbed NHc species, which implies that these species are bonded to the MoOg surface in a manner different than those on the VgOs surface. This explanation does not hold for the MoOg (Cerac) material. NO is consumed when the temperature of the catalyst is in the temperature range 300-390 C, and NO is produced above 390 C. The unsupported catalyst (HDP) shows a peak at 520 C in the TPR spectrum (Fig. 6) and fairly considerable activity and selectivity in the oxidation of ammonia. The MoOa (Cerac) shows no TPR peaks below 870 C but is still active in the oxidation ofNHa (Fig. 1). However, the selectivity to N3 is different. This may be attributed to a difference in surface structure. The MoOs (Cerac) contains far fewer lattice defects (oxygen ion vacancies) at the surface of the oxide than the precipitated MoOs [8]. The number of defects is probably associated with the catalytic activity. The MoOa on SiOg system becomes catalytically active at loadings of 15wt.% and above (Fig. 4). That is, ammonia is selectively oxidised to molecular nitrogen and water (Fig. 3). The TPR spectra of these high-loaded molybdena catalysts show two peaks, at 540 and 590 C (Table 2). However, the catalysts with lead give rise to only one peak at 540 C in the TPR spectrum. Both types of catalysts are active, which implies that the species reducible at 540 C is concerned in the activity of the catalyst. This statement (hypothesis) is supported by the negative results obtained from the use of low-load materials. Amounts of molybdena lower than 15 wt.% on silica do not behave as a catalyst and show no reducible species at 540 C (Table 2). Moreover, from Fig. 7 it is evident that the activity is related to the reducible species which is attributable to the peak at 540 C in the TPR spectrum. The high activity of catalysts with amounts of 15 wt.% of MoOa and more may be explained from the following considerations. It is assumed here that at loadings of MoOg of about 17 wt.% a monolayer of molybdena is present, which ensures complete coverage of the silica support. A complete monolayer on the SiOa used requires an amount of about 20% MoOa, using the most likely crystal plane of the unit cell of MoOa in the calculations (50 A2 per molybdena site). The specific surface area of (20 wt.%) MoOa on SiOg was 140 m2 g~1. The monolayer and complete cover ofMoOs on SiOg give rise to a reducible species at 540 C in the TPR spectrum. The presence of different reducible sites such as silicomolybdic acid, polymolybdate and MoOa at sub-monolayer loadings of MoOs have already been described [9-12]. Barbaux et al. [11] suggest that for a MoOs content between 1.5 and 7.5 wt.% silicomolybdic acid is the main Mo species. Above 7.5 wt.% and below 15 wt.% MoOa, a polymolybdate phase appears, whereas at loadings of ss22.5 wt.% crystalline MoC>3 was found. The specific surface area of the SiOg support used in their study was 130 n^g"1. Indeed, at molybdena loadings higher than about 17 wt.% MoOs we observed a crystalline MoOa phase from the transmission electron micrographs, which is in agreement with the work of 238 Barbaux et al. [11] and of Muzalidhar et al. [12]. Since at these higher molybdena loadings both increased NHs oxidation activity and Hg reducibi- lity (at 540 C) can be observed, it is suggested that a MoOa phase in the catalyst is responsible for the activity of the catalyst. Moreover, it is supposed that this MoOa phase is present at MoOa concentrations close to the monolayer concentration. The role of lead in the catalyst is unclear. Evidence for the presence of obvious species such as basic lead molybdate PbO-PbMo04, was not found. References 1 F. J. J. G. Janssen and F. M.
